message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, worsening back pain associated with prolonged standing or sitting, difficulty actively raising either leg while the knee is extended, and the physical examination with bilateral pain along the sacroiliac joint area and no tenderness during abdominal palpation suggest relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments as the most likely explanation. Placental abruption usually presents with vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. Rheumatoid arthritis usually presents with systemic symptoms and swelling and tenderness in multiple joints. Vertebral bone compression fracture can cause back pain, but the symptoms and physical examination findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms along the sacroiliac joint area with difficulty actively raising the legs suggest the most likely explanation is relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments, a common condition in late pregnancy. Vertebral bone compression fracture and placental abruption would present with different symptoms, and rheumatoid arthritis would not present in this manner during pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pelvic girdle pain, which is a common problem in the third trimester of pregnancy due to the hormonal changes that result in the relaxation of ligaments. There is no evidence of vertebral bone compression fracture or placental abruption, and rheumatoid arthritis is less likely given that motor and sensory function are normal bilaterally.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments typically seen in the third trimester of pregnancy, known as sacroiliac joint pain or pregnancy-related pelvic girdle pain. Option A is unlikely as there is no trauma or risk factors for compression fracture, and motor and sensory function are normal. Option B is also unlikely as there is no vaginal bleeding or abdominal pain which are common symptoms of placental abruption. Option D is unlikely as there is no family history of back pain or morning stiffness which are common symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a relaxation of pelvic girdle ligaments, which is common in late pregnancy due to hormonal changes. Vertebral bone compression fracture would cause localized pain with palpation and movement, and Placental abruption would present with vaginal bleeding and uterine tenderness. Rheumatoid arthritis might be a possibility due to family history, but the symptoms are not consistent with that diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments, which is a common occurrence during the third trimester of pregnancy. The pain along the sacroiliac joint area and difficulty raising the legs are typical of this condition. The absence of other findings such as abdominal tenderness and changes in bowel movements or urination rules out placental abruption and vertebral bone compression fracture. While the patient's mother has rheumatoid arthritis, there is no evidence to suggest the patient has this condition as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments, which is a common condition during pregnancy due to hormonal changes. This can cause sacroiliac joint pain and difficulty with leg movements. Vertebral bone compression fracture will cause localized back pain and tenderness. Placental abruption will cause abdominal pain and uterine tenderness. Rheumatoid arthritis may be a possibility given the patient’s family history, but her symptoms and exam findings do not support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The worsening back pain in a pregnant woman is often due to the relaxation of pelvic girdle ligaments. The bilateral pain along the sacroiliac joint area and difficulty in actively raising either leg while the knee is extended further suggest this diagnosis. Vertebral bone compression fracture and placental abruption are not consistent with the symptoms while the patient's mother having rheumatoid arthritis is not relevant to the patient's diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pelvic girdle pain, which often occurs during the third trimester of pregnancy due to hormonal changes that cause relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments. Vertebral bone compression fracture and placental abruption are associated with more severe symptoms and would likely be accompanied by other signs and symptoms. Rheumatoid arthritis may be a possibility given the patient's family history, but the symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pelvic girdle pain rather than joint involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is at 37 weeks of gestation and has worsening back pain that is worse with extended periods of walking, standing, and sitting, which suggests relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments. The difficulty in raising either leg with the knee extended is also consistent with this diagnosis. The other options are less likely causes of her symptoms.
